TITLE: Germany Appeals to Save Gas After Russia Tightens Flows
SUMMARY: Germany’s economy minister accused Vladimir Putin of trying to raise natural gas prices. Italy, Austria and the Czech Republic also reported gas cuts.

TITLE: Six Takeaways From the Fed’s Meeting on Interest Rates
SUMMARY: The central bank took its most aggressive step yet to try to tame rapid and persistent inflation, raising interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point.

TITLE: Stock Markets Fall After Fed Rally Fades
SUMMARY: Stocks tumbled, with the S&P 500 falling further into bear market territory, as investors focused on the threat that inflation and higher interest rates pose to the economy.

TITLE: Dog Owners Want More Space. Here’s Where They’re Finding It.
SUMMARY: Areas with homes that have pet-friendly features and are close to a dog park are in hot demand, a new analysis shows.

TITLE: A Chinese City May Have Used a Covid App to Block Protesters
SUMMARY: People from across China had set off for the city of Zhengzhou to protest the freezing of their savings. Then they were prevented from moving freely.

TITLE: Infants Died in Fisher-Price Seats That Are Not for Sleep, Safety Commission Said
SUMMARY: The deaths of at least 13 children were associated with the Infant-to-Toddler or Newborn-to-Toddler rockers sold by the company. Congress had outlawed sleepers with an incline.

TITLE: A Rapper’s Delight: Hip-Hop Memorabilia Goes Up for Auction
SUMMARY: Original vinyl records, turntables and other ephemera belonging to the hip-hop pioneer D.J. Kool Herc will be included in a sale at Christie’s.

TITLE: What the Fed’s Rate Hike Means for Credit Cards and Student Loans
SUMMARY: Consumers can expect to pay more for some of life’s most common kinds of borrowing.

TITLE: What the Fed’s Rate Hike Means for Mortgages
SUMMARY: Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages track the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds, which are influenced by inflation and the Fed’s actions, among other things.

TITLE: Internet Explorer Is Shutting Down in a Burst of Nostalgia
SUMMARY: Microsoft will be disabling IE and directing Windows users to its modern Edge web browser in coming months. The news inspired jokes, memes and even some fond memories.

TITLE: Infighting Overshadows Big Plans at The Washington Post
SUMMARY: The aim of Sally Buzbee, The Post’s editor, is to broaden the newspaper’s reach. A year into the job, she’s dealing with internal tumult over some longstanding grievances.

TITLE: Inflation Expected to Remain High Even as Economy Slows and Layoffs Rise
SUMMARY: Inflation is expected to remain high later this year even as the economy slows and layoffs rise. Already, signs of financial stress are surfacing.

TITLE: Gun Control Advocates Have More Money Now, but Money Can’t Buy Zeal
SUMMARY: After more mass shootings, one side is gaining donors and political will; the other is galvanized by gun rights. Will anything be different?

TITLE: SpaceX Said to Fire Employees Involved in Letter Rebuking Elon Musk
SUMMARY: In an email, Gwynne Shotwell, SpaceX’s president, said the letter had made other employees “feel uncomfortable, intimidated and bullied.”

TITLE: Ford recalls 2.9 million vehicles over a flaw in securing the gear shift in park.
SUMMARY: Regulators said 1 percent of the vehicles recalled could have the defect. The products affected include 1.7 million Escape S.U.V.s.

TITLE: Bear markets and recessions happen more often than you think.
SUMMARY: The U.S. has been in recession 14 percent of the time since World War II. But being prepared can minimize hardship and even offer investing opportunities.

TITLE: How Founders Decide What They Should Get Paid
SUMMARY: Whether in a downturn or when things are flush, the compensation that start-up founders give themselves always sends some kind of message.

TITLE: Covid Vaccine and Fisheries Deals Close a ‘Roller Coaster’ W.T.O. Meeting
SUMMARY: Members of the global trade group were forced to scale back plans for more ambitious agreements, but they were ultimately able to reach several deals at a meeting in Geneva.

TITLE: Tether: The Coin That Could Wreck Crypto
SUMMARY: As cryptocurrencies have plunged, attention has focused on a potential point of vulnerability: the market’s reliance on a so-called stablecoin called Tether.

TITLE: Fathers on Playing Video Games With Their Children
SUMMARY: “You can learn a lot from video games: hand-eye coordination and being able to lose.” Fathers talk gaming with their children.

TITLE: Vince McMahon Steps Down From W.W.E. Amid Misconduct Investigation
SUMMARY: Mr. McMahon, the pro wrestling company’s chairman and chief executive, agreed to pay a secret settlement to an employee with whom he was said to have had an affair, The Wall Street Journal reported this week.

TITLE: Tracking the Fear Index on Wall Street
SUMMARY: Plus, with Revlon’s bankruptcy, Wall Street bankers get ready for a wave of distressed situations.

TITLE: Why Some States Are Expanding Tax-Free Periods
SUMMARY: The “holidays” are aimed at helping consumers, but they’re also politically attractive. Tax experts say they provide only modest benefits.

TITLE: Dozens Injured by Hot Coals at Company Event in Zurich
SUMMARY: More than two dozen employees of a Swiss company were injured while walking in bare feet over hot coals, an ancient religious tradition that has become popular on corporate retreats.

TITLE: As Some Office Workers Return, Happy Hour Sees a Wobbly Comeback
SUMMARY: Even as companies struggle to coax employees back to the office, some bars report that their after-work crowds are nearing prepandemic levels.

TITLE: How Can You Travel for $100 or Less a Day? Get a Cruise Deal.
SUMMARY: As companies bring their full fleets back online, many ships still have room. That means bargains are being offered outside the winter “wave season,” making some sailings unexpectedly cheap, even in an era of inflation.

TITLE: Trial of New Alzheimer’s Drug Reports Disappointing Results
SUMMARY: The drug, crenezumab, failed to prevent early symptoms or slow cognitive decline, the latest setback in the long quest to find effective therapies for the disease.

TITLE: BuzzFeed News Names Karolina Waclawiak as Top Editor
SUMMARY: Karolina Waclawiak, its executive editor of culture, takes over the newsroom at a difficult moment for the digital media company.

TITLE: Sales at Art Basel Fair Don’t Show Signs of Downturn
SUMMARY: In the first full in-person fair in its usual June slot since 2019, Art Basel saw numerous big-ticket items sell, including a $40 million Louise Bourgeois spider.

TITLE: In Twitter Meeting, Elon Musk Fields Questions From 8,000 Employees
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk answered questions from Twitter’s 8,000 workers for the first time in a virtual meeting on Thursday.

TITLE: Josh Jensen, Visionary Vintner of Pinot Noir, Is Dead at 78
SUMMARY: His belief in limestone soils led him on a two-year quest for the ideal site for what became the Calera Wine Company: a remote mountain south of San Francisco.

TITLE: E.U. Looks to Tap Gas From Egypt and Israel
SUMMARY: A new agreement could pave the way for more natural gas exports from these countries to reach Europe.

TITLE: Bitcoin Plummets Below $20,000 for First Time Since Late 2020
SUMMARY: Its fall was accelerated in recent weeks by the collapse of two major cryptocurrency projects while sowing doubts about the stability of the overall cryptocurrency market.

TITLE: How to Think About E.S.G. Investing in a Falling Market
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk trashed E.S.G. investing. The S.E.C. is investigating Goldman Sachs’s move into the sector. In a falling market, what should investors consider?

TITLE: Ex-Amazon Worker Convicted in Capital One Hacking
SUMMARY: Paige Thompson’s lawyers said she had been looking for cracks so they could be fixed. A jury found her guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges.

TITLE: ‘The Dirty Secret of Covid’: Scott Galloway on the Postpandemic Economic Turmoil
SUMMARY: Mr. Galloway, an outspoken N.Y.U. professor, speaks with DealBook about the crypto crash and what Silicon Valley will look like on the other side.

TITLE: Gun Sellers Stoke Fears to Boost Weapon Sales
SUMMARY: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.

TITLE: French Nuclear Power Crisis Frustrates Europe’s Push to Quit Russian Energy
SUMMARY: France typically exports electricity, but now it risks blackouts and a need for imported power because of problems at the state nuclear operator.

TITLE: Help! It’s Been More Than 2 Years and I Still Don’t Have the Refund
SUMMARY: Our columnist has received many reader emails complaining of tour operators and travel agencies dragging their feet on refunds for trips or other services. He investigates a $334 fare with Euro Railways.

TITLE: Huge Fire Breaks Out at Sinopec’s Shanghai Complex, Leaving 1 Dead
SUMMARY: Firefighters were able to put the blaze under control, but it caused residents of a nearby neighborhood to flee their homes.

TITLE: Starbucks Executive, Prominent in Push Against Union Drive, Will Leave
SUMMARY: Rossann Williams, president of retail for North America, will depart after 17 years at the company, which said she declined a new position with Starbucks.

TITLE: TikTok says its American traffic is going through Oracle servers, but it retains backups.
SUMMARY: The app is trying to convince the U.S. government that it won’t expose Americans’ information to China.

TITLE: W.T.O. Agrees to Limited Relaxing of Patent Protections on Covid Vaccines
SUMMARY: The agreement is a limited measure that is likely to have little impact on global vaccine supply.

TITLE: Wall Street Has Its Worst Week Since March 2020
SUMMARY: The selling was fueled by persistently high inflation and fears that the Fed’s efforts to tame it with higher interest rates will choke growth.

TITLE: Bear Markets and Recessions Happen More Often Than You Think
SUMMARY: The U.S. has been in recession 14 percent of the time since World War II. But being prepared can minimize hardship and even offer investing opportunities.

TITLE: Why a Rhodes Scholar’s Ambition Led Her to a Job at Starbucks
SUMMARY: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.

TITLE: Apple Workers at Maryland Store Vote to Unionize, a First in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Roughly two-thirds of employees at the store in Towson, Md., voted to join the union.

TITLE: How Work-From-Home Setups Have Changed
SUMMARY: Hybrid or remote work is settling in as a permanent reality for millions. Their setups and technical skills can still feel like a temporary solution.

TITLE: The Week in Business: The Fed Goes Big
SUMMARY: It was a rocky week in the financial markets and for cryto. Elon Musk met with Twitter employees. And there are signs of a slowdown in real estate.

TITLE: ‘Lightyear’ Opens at No. 2, as ‘Jurassic World’ Holds Strong
SUMMARY: The Pixar movie’s estimated $51 million in North American sales fell short of expectations.

TITLE: Tattoo Artists Face a Grayer Palette in Europe
SUMMARY: The E.U. has prohibited some pigments, deeming them potentially hazardous to humans. Artists and manufacturers around the world are struggling to find replacements.

TITLE: A French nuclear crisis frustrates Europe’s push to quit Russian energy.
Dutch Government Activates ‘Early Warning’ Because of Russian Cutbacks on Gas
SUMMARY: The government will allow more burning of coal to generate electricity as gas supplies tighten.

TITLE: Red Flags for Forced Labor Found in China’s Car Battery Supply Chain
SUMMARY: Ties to potentially coercive labor practices could prove a problem for an industry that is heavily dependent on China, once a new law barring Xinjiang products goes into effect.

TITLE: China’s Once-Sizzling Property Market Has Started to Cool
SUMMARY: New home prices in China have fallen, and would-be buyers are thinking twice. That’s bad news for the overall economy.

SUMMARY: Federal law requires banks to reimburse customers for unauthorized electronic transfers, but they often refuse, stranding victims.

SUMMARY: They accuse the companies of depriving them of employee benefits while also denying them the freedoms of independent contractors.

SUMMARY: The tennis star, who has struggled on the court of late, is behind an entertainment company called Hana Kuma in partnership with Mr. James’s fast-growing SpringHill.

TITLE: Tesla Is Forcing the Auto Industry to Rethink How It Sells Cars
SUMMARY: Tesla shifted to selling cars entirely online in 2019. Now, some established automakers, like Ford, are talking about taking a similar approach.

TITLE: Stocks bounce back after a rough week.
SUMMARY: Markets regained some ground after a tumultuous week on Wall Street.

TITLE: I.R.S. Backlog Holds Up Millions of Taxpayer Returns
SUMMARY: The agency started the tax season with more than 8 million unfinished returns from the prior year.

TITLE: Senior Black Executives Depart Amazon as It Names New Consumer Boss
SUMMARY: The company’s sprawling consumer and operations business has experienced a significant shake-up in recent weeks.

SUMMARY: HUD had accused Meta’s housing advertising system of discriminating against Facebook users based on their race, gender, religion and other characteristics.

TITLE: What people are saying about the chance of a U.S. recession.
SUMMARY: The possibility of an economic downturn has become a major point of discussion, with chatter on Wall Street, in the White House and beyond.

TITLE: Stocks Rebound After a Rough Week
SUMMARY: Markets regained some ground after a tumultuous week on Wall Street.

TITLE: Yellen May Soon Get Her Signature on the Dollar
SUMMARY: While the Treasury secretary sat for her official currency signing more than a year ago, under arcane rules her signature has not yet appeared on the U.S. dollar.

TITLE: The Russian Ruble Keeps Rising, Hitting a Seven-Year High
SUMMARY: A combination of capital controls, rising exports and falling imports have strengthened the Russian currency since it plunged in the weeks after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

SUMMARY: A BuzzFeed report raises questions about Biden’s approach to TikTok and Chinese deal-making.

SUMMARY: Jumbo Floating Restaurant, which closed in 2020, capsized in the South China Sea after being towed from the city. The sinking triggered nostalgia for a happier period of Hong Kong history.

SUMMARY: One company says it has the technology. And though investors looking for cleaner power generation are lining up, some environmentalists are skeptical.

SUMMARY: Travel was disrupted for tens of millions of people during the country’s biggest walkout in decades as union leaders warned of a summer of labor unrest.

SUMMARY: With regular gasoline around $5 per gallon, suspending the federal gas tax would provide a measure of relief for consumers, but Congress would need to take action.

TITLE: To Pressure Taiwan, China is Now Targeting its Grouper Exports

SUMMARY: Billions of dollars could be at stake as a law banning imports of some products from China goes into effect.

SUMMARY: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, testified before a Senate committee at a moment of rapid inflation and rising interest rates.

SUMMARY: The news start-up Semafor has raised $25 million from wealthy individuals, with a goal of cultivating direct relationships between its journalists and its audience.

SUMMARY: A court found Zhang Guo guilty of “forcible indecency.” The tech giant fired his accuser last year after she claimed that he had molested her and that her boss had raped her.

SUMMARY: The decision broadens the possible legal exposure to the highest ranks of the Fox media empire.

TITLE: China Tariffs Are Important Source of Leverage, Says Biden’s Top Trade Negotiator
SUMMARY: The Biden administration has come under pressure to ease tariffs as a way to help deal with inflation.

SUMMARY: The media mogul’s fourth divorce is unlikely to change the ownership structure of Mr. Murdoch’s empire, but it could reverberate through companies such as Fox News and The Wall Street Journal.

SUMMARY: Home sales are flagging and the rest of the economy is expected to slow, maybe sharply, as rates increase. Why is the Federal Reserve doing this?

TITLE: The I.R.S. Backlog of Unprocessed Tax Returns Has Grown to 21 Million
SUMMARY: The national taxpayer advocate criticized the Biden administration for being slow to make changes at the Internal Revenue Service.

TITLE: Powell Says Fed Looking for ‘Compelling Evidence’ that Inflation is Cooling
SUMMARY: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, testified before a Senate committee at a moment of rapid inflation and rising interest rates.

TITLE: Will Biden’s Gas Tax Holiday Make a Difference?
SUMMARY: Many economists say suspending federal taxes on gas will not significantly cut prices for consumers.

TITLE: Clean Energy Investment Lags as Oil and Gas Prices Soar
SUMMARY: The head of the International Energy Agency said high prices for fossil fuels would probably persist for years.

TITLE: There’s an ‘Unprecedented’ Sriracha Shortage Right Now
SUMMARY: An abysmal spring harvest of Mexican chiles caused an “unprecedented shortage” of Asian hot sauces, a California-based producer said.

SUMMARY: Proposed alternatives include exporting into Poland or transporting it into Romania and out through the Black Sea port of Constanta.

SUMMARY: The scheme, which the authorities say used “aggressive and deceptive tactics,” defrauded more than 150 people of about $13 million, according to court documents.

TITLE: UK Inflation Rate Reaches 40-Year High of 9.1 Percent
SUMMARY: The latest data comes during crippling train strikes as workers demand pay in line with the rising cost of living.

TITLE: Nonbinary Airline Passengers Ask: What’s Gender Got to Do With It?
SUMMARY: Despite recent federal changes meant to better include gender-diverse travelers, most U.S. airlines still require passengers to select “male” or “female” when booking a ticket.

SUMMARY: A financial executive and sometime sports entrepreneur, he was thwarted in his quixotic quest to help homeowners with underwater mortgages during the Great Recession.

SUMMARY: The move would be an effort to further wean Americans from addictive tobacco products and reduce smoking-related illnesses.

TITLE: The Obamas’ Production Company Signs With Amazon’s Audible After Lapsed Spotify Deal
SUMMARY: The agreement comes after a three-year deal the former president and first lady had with Spotify lapsed.

SUMMARY: Mark Zuckerberg, who once said securing elections was “the most important thing,” has shifted Meta’s focus to the metaverse. That may have real-world implications.

TITLE: Government to Cancel $6 Billion in Student Loans for Defrauded Borrowers
SUMMARY: Around 200,000 who sought relief after attending schools that the Education Department said showed signs of “substantial misconduct” will have their federal student loans wiped out.

TITLE: The Rise of the 0.5 Selfie
SUMMARY: These selfies, taken with an ultra-wide-angle lens, aren’t fussed over. Sometimes they are just “distorted and crazy.”

TITLE: Fed officials pledge ‘unconditional’ dedication to lowering inflation.
SUMMARY: Central bankers are taking aggressive action to lower price increases. On Thursday, they signaled a willingness to keep going, despite the economic pain it could cause.

TITLE: Netflix Lays Off Another 300 Employees
SUMMARY: The company is trying to reduce costs while it confronts declining subscriber growth.

TITLE: Fed Officials Pledge ‘Unconditional’ Dedication to Lowering Inflation
SUMMARY: Central bankers are taking aggressive action to lower price increases. On Thursday, they signaled a willingness to keep going, despite the economic pain it could cause.

TITLE: FDA Orders Juul to Remove E-Cigarette Products from U.S. Market
SUMMARY: The agency ruled against the company’s application to stay on the market, a decisive blow to a once-popular vaping brand that appealed to teenagers.

SUMMARY: Germany’s economy minister triggered the second stage of a contingency plan a week after Russia cut back on gas to Europe, sending prices soaring and raising fears of shortages.

SUMMARY: The streaming service is reportedly talking to Comcast and Google as it seeks to create an ad-supported offering.

SUMMARY: Mitoshi Matsumoto, who defied corporate edicts by closing for a few hours every night, was ordered by a judge to hand over his store near Osaka, Japan, and pay damages to the corporate giant.

TITLE: What to See, Eat and Do in New Orleans
SUMMARY: Immersive art, bespoke hotels and restaurants that range from Creole to a ‘tropical roadhouse’ are only a few of the offerings awaiting visitors.

TITLE: Art World Confronts Its Challenges
SUMMARY: From climate change to the value of digital creations, to looking beyond Earth to deciding who really owns art — the issues are enormous and growing.

TITLE: Cost of Owning a Home Surges Above the Cost of Renting One
SUMMARY: A new report shows that having a mortgage is far more expensive than having a lease, a disparity that is helping to cool a red-hot housing market.

TITLE: What Fed Chair Powell has said about inflation, interest rates and the risk of a recession.

SUMMARY: South Korea’s export-driven economy makes it particularly sensitive to conditions in the global economy.

TITLE: Russia Cuts Gas Flows as Europe Races to Stock Up for Winter
SUMMARY: The routine summer practice of filling Europe’s natural gas tanks has become a battle after Russia cut deliveries by more than half.

TITLE: Inflation Complicates Biden’s Deliberations on Student Loan Forgiveness
SUMMARY: The president is trying to balance his campaign promise to cancel thousands of dollars in student debt for tens of millions of borrowers with concerns such a move would be seen as a handout.

TITLE: Judge Allows Dominion’s Defamation Suit to Include Fox Corporation
SUMMARY: The decision broadens the possible legal exposure to the highest ranks of the Fox media empire.

TITLE: Labor Agency Seeks Broad Order Against Starbucks in Federal Court
SUMMARY: The National Labor Relations Board is aiming to stop what it says is extensive illegal activity by the coffee chain amid a national union campaign.

TITLE: Jerome Powell, Fed Chair, Says Recession Is ‘Certainly a Possibility’
SUMMARY: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, testified before a Senate committee at a moment of rapid inflation and rising interest rates.

SUMMARY: With famine threatening millions, Europe is intent on finding alternatives to one of world’s biggest food exporters, whose landlocked crop is stranded by war.

TITLE: ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ Becomes a New Way to Pay for Guns
SUMMARY: Credova, a little-known fintech company, is leading the way in offering installment plans to buyers of guns and hunting supplies.

TITLE: How to Start Investing in a Bear Market
SUMMARY: The immediate outlook is grim, but low-cost funds that track the entire market can help you prosper over the long term, our columnist says.

SUMMARY: Their purchases of Russian crude are undermining the West’s efforts to isolate the Kremlin and upending the global oil markets.

TITLE: Fed Confronts a ‘New World’ of Inflation
SUMMARY: Central banks had a longstanding playbook for how inflation worked. In the postpandemic era, all bets are off.

SUMMARY: Since New York’s eviction moratorium ended in January, tenants and their landlords are returning to housing court.

TITLE: What Is A Recession and When Is the Next One Going to Begin?
SUMMARY: Recessions since World War II have lasted just over 10 months each, on average. The last one, which began in 2020, lasted just two months.

SUMMARY: “American Buffalo,” at Circle in the Square, is sticking with masking till it closes, July 10, citing the “proximity of the audience to the actors” and “the staging in the round.”

TITLE: What’s Next for Juul and E-Cigarettes?
SUMMARY: The company is appealing the F.D.A.’s ruling that it stop selling its vaping products. Whether they will remain on the market in the interim has yet to be decided.

SUMMARY: A handful of companies have committed to helping their employees access abortion services.

TITLE: Politico’s Roe v. Wade Scoop Becomes Law
SUMMARY: In May, Politico’s reporters published a draft opinion outlining the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Today, the high court made it official.

TITLE: Stocks Regain Ground, Set For a Rare Weekly Gain
SUMMARY: The S&P 500 is on track for a gain of more than 5 percent this week, only its second positive week in the past twelve.

TITLE: After the Gun Ruling
SUMMARY: Plus, Intel pressures Congress to provide funding for U.S. chip production.

TITLE: Fed Stress Tests Show Banks Can Withstand Severe Recession
SUMMARY: The annual tests hold new significance as inflation persists and signs of a coming downturn continue to accumulate.

TITLE: Citadel Says It Will Move Offices to Miami Because of Crime in Chicago
SUMMARY: The hedge fund made the announcement after simmering tensions between its founder and the Illinois governor.
